docs.lead_paragraph: Wall Street stocks fell on Thursday as investors reacted with caution to a drop in the price of oil. An announcement by President Obama of a job creation initiative failed to motivate investors, The New York Times's Javier C. Hernandez reported.

headline.main: Oil Slides, and Wall Street Pulls Back

docs.abstract: Wall Street stocks fell on Thursday as investors reacted with caution to a drop in the price of oil. An announcement by President Obama of a job creation initiative failed to motivate investors.

docs.lead_paragraph: Which should we trust to rein in health care costs: the federal government or the private sector? A brief analysis by the Congressional Joint Economic Committee's ranking Republican, Senator Sam Brownback, above, of Kansas, compared the rates of health care spending growth from 1997 to 2006 in the United States and in the 29 other countries in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
docs.abstract: Brief analysis by Congressional Joint Economic Committee's ranking Republican Sen Sam Brownback of Kansas concludes that giving government more control over health care in US would be big mistake; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats are trying to build popular support for health care legislation by enlisting people who voted in the presidential election last year for Barack Obama. Organizing for America, the Obama campaign arm of the Democratic National Committee, sent e-mail messages on Thursday to Obama supporters in 32 Congressional districts represented by Republicans. They are districts that voted for Mr. Obama in 2008 but whose representatives voted against health care legislation in the House last Saturday.
docs.abstract: Organizing for America, Democratic National Committee's campaign arm, sends out e-mail messages to supporters of Pres Obama in 32 Congressional districts represented by Republicans to try to build support for health care legislation; photo (M)
